facts.text: This is Original Jurisdiction Petition No. XXIX of 1950 filed as an application under article 32 of the Constitution of India for writs of certiorari and prohibition against the Chief Commissioner of Delhi.

anchor.surface_text: ORIGINAL JURISDICTION Petition No. XXIX of 1950. Application under article 32 of the Constitution of India for a writ of certiorari and prohibition. The facts are stated in the judgment. C. Chatterjee  B. Banerji, with him  for the petition- er.

facts.text: C. Chatterjee and B. Banerji appeared for the petitioner.

anchor.surface_text: C. Chatterjee  B. Banerji, with him  for the petition- er. C. Setalvad, Attorney-General for India,  S. M. Sikri, with him  for the respondent. 1950. May 26.

facts.text: C. Setalvad, Attorney-General for India, and S. M. Sikri appeared for the respondent.

anchor.surface_text: C. Setalvad, Attorney-General for India,  S. M. Sikri, with him  for the respondent. 1950. May 26. The judgment of Kania C.J., Patanjali Sastri, Mehr Chand Mahajan, Mukherjea and Das JJ. was deliv- ered by Patanjali Sastri J.

facts.text: The case was heard on May 26, 1950.

anchor.surface_text: 1950. May 26. The judgment of Kania C.J., Patanjali Sastri, Mehr Chand Mahajan, Mukherjea and Das JJ. was deliv- ered by Patanjali Sastri J. Fazl Ali J. delivered a separate dissenting judgment, PATANJALI SASTRI J.--This is an application under arti-

facts.text: Judgment delivered by Patanjali Sastri J. for Kania C.J., Patanjali Sastri, Mehr Chand Mahajan, Mukherjea and Das JJ.

anchor.surface_text: The judgment of Kania C.J., Patanjali Sastri, Mehr Chand Mahajan, Mukherjea and Das JJ. was deliv- ered by Patanjali Sastri J. Fazl Ali J. delivered a separate dissenting judgment, PATANJALI SASTRI J.--This is an application under arti- cle 32 of the Constitution praying for the issue of writs of certiorari and prohibition to the respondent, the Chief Commissioner of Delhi,

facts.text: Fazl Ali J. delivered a separate dissenting judgment.

anchor.surface_text: Fazl Ali J. delivered a separate dissenting judgment, PATANJALI SASTRI J.--This is an application under arti- cle 32 of the Constitution praying for the issue of writs of certiorari and prohibition to the respondent, the Chief Commissioner of Delhi, with a view to examine the legality of and quash the order made by him in regard to an English weekly of Delhi called the Organizer

facts.text: The petitioners are the printer and publisher (first applicant, Shri Brij Bhushan) and editor (second applicant, Shri K.R. Halkani) of the Organizer, an English weekly of Delhi.

anchor.surface_text: to the respondent, the Chief Commissioner of Delhi, with a view to examine the legality of and quash the order made by him in regard to an English weekly of Delhi called the Organizer of which the first applicant is the printer and publisher, and the second is the editor. On 2nd March, 1950, the respondent, in exercise of powers conferred on him by section 7 (1) (c) of the East Punjab Public Safety Act, 1949,

facts.text: On 2nd March 1950, the Chief Commissioner of Delhi, Shankar Prasad, issued an order under section 7(1)(c) of the East Punjab Public Safety Act, 1949, extended to Delhi Province.

anchor.surface_text: On 2nd March, 1950, the respondent, in exercise of powers conferred on him by section 7  1   c  of the East Punjab Public Safety Act, 1949, which has been extended to the Delhi Province and is hereinafter referred to as the impugned Act, issued the following order Whereas the Chief Commissioner, Delhi, is satisfied that Organizer, an English weekly of Delhi, has been pub- lishing highly objectionable matter constituting a threat to public law and order

facts.text: The Chief Commissioner was satisfied that the Organizer has been publishing highly objectionable matter constituting a threat to public law and order.

anchor.surface_text: Whereas the Chief Commissioner, Delhi, is satisfied that Organizer, an English weekly of Delhi, has been pub- lishing highly objectionable matter constituting a threat to public law and order and that action as is hereinafter mentioned is necessary for the purpose of preventing or combating activities prejudicial to the public safety or the maintenance of public order.

facts.text: The order requires the petitioners to submit for scrutiny, in duplicate before publication till further orders, all communal matter and news and views about Pakistan including photographs and cartoons other than those from official sources or specified news agencies.

anchor.surface_text: Now therefore in exercise of the powers conferred by section 7  1  c  of the East Punjab Public Safety Act, 1949, as extended to the Delhi Province, I, Shankar Prasad, Chief Commissioner, Delhi, do by this order require you Shri Brij Bhushan, Printer and Publisher and Shri K.R. Halkani, Editor of the aforesaid paper to submit for scrutiny, in duplicate, before publication, till further orders, all communal matter and news and views about Pakistan including photographs and cartoons other than those derived from official sources or supplied by the news agencies, viz., Press Trust of India, United Press of India and United Press of America to the Provincial Press Officer,

facts.text: The East Punjab Public Safety Act, 1949 was extended to the Delhi Province.

anchor.surface_text: viz., Press Trust of India, United Press of India and United Press of America to the Provincial Press Officer, or in his absence, to Superintend- ent of Press Branch at his office at 5, Alipur Road, Civil Lines, Delhi, between the hours 10 a.m. and 5 p.m. on work- ing days. The only point argued before us relates to the constitutional validity of section 7  1   c  of the impugned Act which, as appears from its preamble, was passed to provide special measures to ensure public safety and maintenance of public order.

facts.text: The East Punjab Public Safety Act, 1949 was passed to provide special measures to ensure public safety and maintenance of public order.

anchor.surface_text: The only point argued before us relates to the constitutional validity of section 7  1   c  of the impugned Act which, as appears from its preamble, was passed to provide special measures to ensure public safety and maintenance of public order. Section 7  1   c  under which the aforesaid order purports to have been made reads  so far as material here  as follows -- The Provincial Government or any authority authorised by it in this behalf if satisfied that such action is neces- sary for the purpose of preventing or combating any activity prejudicial to the public safety or the maintenance of public order may, by order in writing addressed to a print- er, publisher or editor require that any matter relating to a particular subject or class of subjects shall before publication be submitted for scrutiny.

facts.text: Section 7(1)(c) of the East Punjab Public Safety Act, 1949 authorizes the Provincial Government or authorized authority to require pre-publication scrutiny of matter relating to a particular subject if necessary for preventing or combating activity prejudicial to public safety or public order.

anchor.surface_text: Section 7  1   c  under which the aforesaid order purports to have been made reads  so far as material here  as follows -- The Provincial Government or any authority authorised by it in this behalf if satisfied that such action is neces- sary for the purpose of preventing or combating any activity prejudicial to the public safety or the maintenance of public order may, by order in writing addressed to a print- er, publisher or editor require that any matter relating to a particular subject or class of subjects shall before publication be submitted for scrutiny. The petitioners claim that this provision infringes the fundamental right to the freedom of speech and expression conferred upon them by article 19  1   a  of the Constitu- tion

facts.text: Petitioners claim that section 7(1)(c) infringes Article 19(1)(a) and is not justified under Article 19(2).

anchor.surface_text: The petitioners claim that this provision infringes the fundamental right to the freedom of speech and expression conferred upon them by article 19  1   a  of the Constitu- tion inasmuch as it authorises the imposition of a restric- tion on the publication of the journal which is not justi- fied under clause  2  of that article. There can be little doubt that the imposition of precen- sorship on a journal is a restriction on the liberty of the press which is an essential part of the right to freedom of speech and expression declared by article 19  1   a .

facts.text: The majority court quashed the impugned order dated 2nd March 1950 following the decision in Petition No. XVI of 1950.

anchor.surface_text: As this question turns on considerations which are essentially the same as those on which our decision in Petition No. XVI of 1950 2  was based, our judgment in that case concludes the present case also. Accordingly, for the reasons indicated in that judgment, we allow this petition and hereby quash the impugned order of the Chief Commission- er, Delhi, dated the 2nd March, 1950.

facts.text: Fazl Ali J. in dissent held that section 7(1)(c) is saved by Article 19(2).

anchor.surface_text: In my opinion, the law which is impugned is fully saved by article 19  2  and if it cannot be successfully assailed it is not possible to grant the remedy which the petitioners are seeking here.

facts.text: The East Punjab Public Safety Act, 1949 was passed by the Provincial Legislature under section 100 of Government of India Act 1935 read with Entry 1 List II Seventh Schedule (public order).

anchor.surface_text: The East Punjab Public Safety Act, 1949, of which sec- tion 7 is a part, was passed by the Provincial Legislature in exercise of the power conferred upon it by section 100 of the Government of India Act, 1935, is read with Entry 1 of List II of the Seventh Schedule to that Act, which includes among other matters public order.

facts.text: Delhi Province has been notified as a dangerously disturbed area under section 20 of the East Punjab Public Safety Act, 1949.

anchor.surface_text: I find that section 20 of the impugned Act provides that the Provincial Government may by notification declare that the whole or any part of the Province as may be specified in the notification is a dangerously disturbed area. This provision has some bearing on the aim and object of the Act, and we cannot overlook it when considering its scope. It may be incidentally mentioned that we have been informed that, under this section, Delhi Province has been notified to be a dangerously disturbed area.

facts.text: The petitioners pray to quash the order made by the Chief Commissioner on 2nd March 1950.

anchor.surface_text: with a view to examine the legality of and quash the order made by him in regard to an English weekly of Delhi called the Organizer of which the first applicant is the printer and publisher, and the second is the editor.

facts.text: The submission for scrutiny is to the Provincial Press Officer or Superintendent of Press Branch at 5, Alipur Road, Civil Lines, Delhi, between 10 a.m. and 5 p.m. on working days.

arguments.claim: East Punjab Public Safety Act, 1949 passed under power for public order in GOIA 1935, covering public tranquillity

anchor.surface_text: The East Punjab Public Safety Act, 1949, of which sec- tion 7 is a part, was passed by the Provincial Legislature in exercise of the power conferred upon it by section 100 of the Government of India Act, 1935, is read with Entry 1 of List II of the Seventh Schedule to that Act, which includes among other matters public order.

arguments.claim: Public safety in the Act means security of the State

anchor.surface_text: At this stage, it will be convenient to consider the meaning of another expression public safety which is used throughout the impugned Act and which is also chosen by its framers for its title. This expression, though it has been variously used in different contexts see the Indian Penal Code, Ch. XIV , has not acquired

arguments.claim: Public order and public safety are allied; public disorder covers small riots, public unsafety/insecurity of State covers serious disorders jeopardizing State security

anchor.surface_text: This expression in the general sense may be construed to have reference to the maintenance of what is generally known as law and order in the Province, and this is confirmed by the words which follow it in Entry 1 of List II and which have been put within brackets, viz., but not including the use of naval,

arguments.claim: Act provides special measures for serious public disorders affecting security of State, not ordinary cases

anchor.surface_text: Thus public order and public safety are allied matters, but, in order to appreciate how they stand in relation to each other, it seems best to direct our atten- tion to the opposite concepts which we may, for convenience of reference, respectively label as public disorder and public unsafety.

arguments.claim: Public safety and maintenance of public order are closely allied concepts, interchangeable in context; 'or' not disjunctive

anchor.surface_text: In construing the Act, we must try to get at its aim and purpose, and before the Act is declared to be invalid, we must see whether it is capable of being so construed as to bear a reasonable meaning consistent with its validity.

arguments.claim: Article 19(2) uses 'undermines security of State' to cover sedition and related matters without using 'sedition' due to conflicting judicial views

anchor.surface_text: the latest pronouncement by the highest Indian tribunal as to the law of sedition is to be found in Niharendu Dutt Majumdar v. The King which has been quoted again and again and in which Gwyer C.J. laid down that public disorder, or the reasonable anticipation or likelihood of public disorder, is the gist of the offence

arguments.claim: Sedition and public disorder undermine security of State; Act prevents such, thus saved by Article 19(2)

arguments.claim: Liberty of the press consists in no previous restraints on publications

anchor.surface_text: As pointed out by Blackstone in his Commentaries the liberty of the press consists in laying no previous restraint upon publications, and not in freedom from censure for criminal matter when published. Every freeman has an undoubted right to lay what sentiments he pleases before the public; to forbid this,

holdings.text: The imposition of pre-censorship on a journal is a restriction on the liberty of the press which is an essential part of the right to freedom of speech and expression declared by article 19(1)(a).

anchor.surface_text: There can be little doubt that the imposition of precen- sorship on a journal is a restriction on the liberty of the press which is an essential part of the right to freedom of speech and expression declared by article 19  1  a .

holdings.reasoning_summary: Liberty of the press consists in laying no previous restraint upon publications, as stated by Blackstone.

holdings.text: Section 7(1)(c) of the East Punjab Public Safety Act, 1949, which authorises the imposition of pre-censorship, does not fall within the reservation of clause (2) of Article 19.

anchor.surface_text: The only question therefore is whether section 7  1  c which authorises the imposition-of such a restriction falls within the reservation of clause  2  of article 19. As this question turns on companysiderations which are essentially the same as those on which our decision in Petition No. XVI of 1950 2  was based, our judgment

holdings.reasoning_summary: The question is concluded by the decision in Petition No. XVI of 1950 (Romesh Thapar v. State of Madras) on identical considerations.

holdings.text: The petition is allowed and the impugned order dated 2nd March 1950 is quashed.

anchor.surface_text: As this question turns on considerations which are essentially the same as those on which our decision in Petition No. XVI of 1950 2  was based, our judgment in that case concludes the present case also. Accordingly, for the reasons indicated in that judgment, we allow this petition and hereby quash the impugned order of the Chief Commission- er, Delhi, dated the 2nd March, 1950.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Application of the holding from Petition No. XVI of 1950 that such restrictions are not saved by Article 19(2).

holdings.text: Section 7(1)(c) of the East Punjab Public Safety Act, 1949 is valid and fully saved by Article 19(2).

anchor.surface_text: In my opinion, the law which is impugned is fully saved by article 19  2  and if it cannot be successfully assailed it is not possible to grant the remedy which the petitioners are seeking here.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Public safety equates to security of the State; public order allied to it; Act targets serious disorders undermining State security; avoids 'sedition' due to judicial conflicts but covered by 'undermines security of State'; harmonious construction with constitutional limits.

holdings.text: Clause (2) of Article 19 does not stand in the way of the petitioners as the impugned provision relates to matters undermining the security of the State.

anchor.surface_text: There can be no doubt that to impose pre-censorship on a journal, such as has been ordered by the Chief Commissioner in this case, is a restriction on the liberty of the press which is included in the right to freedom of speech and expression guaranteed by article 19  1   a  of the Constitu- tion, and the only question which we have therefore to decide is whether clause  2  of article 19 stands in the way of the petitioners.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Pre-censorship accepted as restriction but saved as Act prevents activities prejudicial to public safety/public order equated to State security.

anchor.surface_text: Petition No. XVI of 1950 2  was based, our judgment in that case companycludes the present case also. Accordingly, for the reasons indicated in that judgment, we allow this petition and hereby quash the impugned order of the Chief Commission- er, Delhi, dated the 2nd March, 1950.

precedents.citation: Rex v. Governor of Wormwood Scrubbs Prison

anchor.surface_text: Rex v. Governor of Wormwood Scrubbs Prison 1 . The headnote of this case runs as follows By section 1 of the Defence of the Realm  Consolidation  Act, 1914, power was given to His Majesty in Council during the companytinuance of the present war to issue regula- tions for securing the public safety and the de- fence of the realm --  1  1920 2 K.B. 305.

precedents.case_name: Rex v. Governor of Wormwood Scrubbs Prison
precedents.cited_proposition: "public safety" includes regulations for prevention of internal disorder and rebellion, not limited to foreign enemies
precedents.cited_holding: the regulations thereby authorized were number limited to regulations for the protection of the companyntry against foreign enemies, but included regulations designed for the prevention of internal disorder and rebellion

precedents.citation: Niharendu Dutt Majumdar v. The King

anchor.surface_text: Niharendu Dutt Majumdar v. The King 1  which has been quoted again and again and in which Gwyer C.J. laid down that public disor- der, or the reasonable anticipation or likelihood of public disorder, is the gist of the offence of sedition

precedents.case_name: Niharendu Dutt Majumdar v. The King
precedents.cited_proposition: Public disorder, or reasonable anticipation thereof, is the gist of sedition; acts or words must incite to disorder or have that tendency

anchor.surface_text: Cave J. in his charge to the jury in a case relating to the law of sedition JR. v. Burns 2  said -- The law upon the question of what is seditious and what is number is to be found stated very clearly in a book by Stephen

precedents.cited_proposition: Stephen's statement on sedition approved by commissioners

precedents.citation: King Emperor v. Sadhashiv Narayan Bhalerao

anchor.surface_text: King Emper- or v. Sadhashiv Narayan Bhalerao 3  that the test laid down by the learned Chief Justice was number applicable in India where the offence under section 124A of the Indian Penal Code should be companystrued with reference to the words used in that section.

precedents.case_name: King Emperor v. Sadashiv Narayan Bhalerao
precedents.cited_proposition: Sedition under s.124A IPC does not require incitement to disorder; marginal note 'sedition' is not operative
precedents.cited_holding: Their Lordships are unable to find anything in the language of either section 124A or the Rule which companyld suggest that the acts or words companyplained of must either incite to disorder or must be such as to satisfy reasonable men that this is their intention or tendency.

anchor.surface_text: There can be no doubt that to impose pre-censorship on a journal, such as has been ordered by the Chief Commissioner in this case, is a restriction on the liberty of the press which is included in the right to freedom of speech and expression guaranteed by article 19  1   a  of the Constitu- tion, and the only question which we have therefore to decide is whether clause  2  of article 19 stands in the way of the petitioners.
